instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the inversion models in the study and how far can this metric go in the related study on the rapid and accurate acquisition of soil salinity (SS) information in the Yellow River Delta?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the inversion models in the study was the calibration coefficient of determination (R-2) and root mean square error (RMSE). The R-2 value measures the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable (soil salinity) that can be explained by the independent variables (spectral bands/indices). The RMSE value represents the average difference between the predicted and actual values of soil salinity.

The study found that the BPNN model had the highest inversion accuracy, with an R-2 value of 0.769 and an RMSE value of 1.342 during calibration. During validation, the R-2 value was 0.774 and the RMSE value was 1.975. These metrics indicate the level of accuracy and precision of the model in estimating soil salinity.

However, the study does not mention how far these metrics can go in terms of their range or limitations. It is important to note that the interpretation of R-2 and RMSE values may vary depending on the specific context and field of study.
